title: Quiz 10: Comprehensive Review
topicName: Unit Three Part One: Labour and Puerperium
description: Comprehensive review of labour, puerperium, and neonatal care concepts

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a sign of true labour?
questions.explanation: True labour contractions typically continue and increase in intensity with ambulation. Relief of pain with ambulation is characteristic of false labour (Braxton Hicks contractions).
questions.hint: True labour contractions don't go away when you move around.

questions.question: What is the normal duration of the third stage of labour?
questions.explanation: The normal duration of the third stage of labour (delivery of the placenta) is 5-15 minutes. Prolonged third stage (longer than 30 minutes) increases the risk of postpartum hemorrhage.
questions.hint: This stage is typically the shortest.

questions.question: Lochia rubra is the normal vaginal discharge for the first 3-4 days postpartum.
questions.explanation: True. Lochia rubra is the red vaginal discharge containing blood that is normally present for the first 3-4 days postpartum. It then transitions to lochia serosa (pinkish) and finally lochia alba (white/yellowish).

questions.question: Which of the following are components of the Apgar score? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: The Apgar score has 5 components: Appearance (color), Pulse (heart rate), Grimace (reflex irritability), Activity (muscle tone), and Respiration. Temperature is not part of the Apgar score.
questions.hint: The acronym APGAR stands for these 5 criteria.

questions.question: Match each lochia stage with its characteristics:
questions.explanation: Lochia rubra = red, bloody discharge (days 1-4); Lochia serosa = pinkish-brown discharge (days 4-10); Lochia alba = white/yellowish discharge (days 10-21). This progression is normal postpartum.
questions.hint: The color changes from red to pink to white/yellow.

questions.question: The '4 Ts' of postpartum hemorrhage are Tone, Trauma, Tissue, and ___BLANK___.
questions.explanation: The '4 Ts' of postpartum hemorrhage are Tone (uterine atony), Trauma (genital tract injury), Tissue (retained placental tissue), and Thrombin (coagulation disorders). This mnemonic helps remember the causes.

questions.question: What is the most common cause of early-onset neonatal sepsis?
questions.explanation: Group B Streptococcus (GBS) is the most common cause of early-onset neonatal sepsis (within 72 hours of birth). It is transmitted from the mother during delivery.
questions.hint: This organism is commonly found in the maternal genital tract.

questions.question: What is the primary treatment for severe respiratory distress syndrome in preterm infants?
questions.explanation: Surfactant replacement therapy is the primary treatment for severe respiratory distress syndrome in preterm infants. It replaces the deficient surfactant and improves lung compliance.
questions.hint: This treatment replaces what preterm infants lack.

questions.question: Therapeutic hypothermia (cooling) is effective for treating hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy if initiated within 6 hours of birth.
questions.explanation: True. Therapeutic hypothermia (cooling to 33.5Â°C for 72 hours) is effective for treating moderate to severe hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy if initiated within the critical 6-hour window after birth.
questions.hint: Timing is critical for this treatment.

questions.question: What is the HELPERR mnemonic used for in obstetrics?
questions.explanation: The HELPERR mnemonic is used for the systematic management of shoulder dystocia: H - Help, E - Episiotomy, L - Legs (McRoberts), P - Pressure, E - Enter maneuvers, R - Remove posterior arm, R - Roll.
questions.hint: This is used when the baby's shoulders get stuck during delivery.
